nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) causes an artifactual prediction of monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon prices during long-term energy transitions, misleading policy conclusions
Major IAMs implement CES or nested-CES functional forms for production and energy technology substitution across sectors
CES is conceptually designed for factor substitution among economic inputs (e.g., capital and labor) with fixed shares and constant elasticity, and is share-preserving by construction

Applying CES to technical energy-factor substitution (fossil fuels by renewables) mathematically requires exponentially increasing amounts of the substitute as substitution progresses, implying an exponentially rising marginal carbon price

Stylized CES example implemented for fossil (F) and renewable (R) inputs (with derivation of MRTS and price ratio equations) shows: (i) increasing R required to replace F, (ii) saturation far from complete substitution, (iii) small initial carbon price rising exponentially, and (iv) strong sensitivity to elasticity parameter

Method: derive CES production and MRTS relations, solve Lagrangian for two-good competitive market (F and R), compute relative price PF/PR and implied carbon tax C = pF - cF under scenarios of constant or decreasing PR and growing energy demand
Historical technological and energy-system transitions empirically follow S-curve diffusion (logistic, Gompertz, Bass models) with dynamically changing elasticity and learning-driven cost reductions

Observed results from several mainstream IAMs and hybrid models (e.g., GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE) exhibit exponentially increasing carbon prices and limited substitution to renewables consistent with CES-driven artifacts

Policy implications of the CES-driven artifacts include: price diversion (overreliance on carbon price rather than physical planning), sticker shock (perception of prohibitive mitigation costs), and technological myopia (models favor incumbent technologies already in formulation)

A proposed methodological modification is to use a dynamically varying elasticity of substitution (declining elasticity over time or calibrated to technological diffusion) within IAM formulations to better represent S-curve transitions

Result: implementing dynamic elasticity in the stylized CES framework yields substitution and carbon-price trajectories consistent with S-curve diffusion and bounded carbon price peaks, removing the exponential artifact

Conclusion and recommendation: IAMs should adopt dynamic-elasticity formulations or move toward physics-driven energy models and explicit deployment targets instead of relying primarily on price signals derived from static CES to produce policy-relevant scenarios

Assumption/limitation: CES was originally intended for capital-labor substitution where complete domination by one factor is unlikely and substitution ranges are limited; this context differs from long-term technical substitutions where full replacement and evolving elasticity occur

Supporting evidence: empirical cost trajectories (declining LCOE for wind and solar, falling battery costs, feasible long-term storage and system studies) imply backstop/substitute costs are bounded and typically fall with diffusion, so carbon prices need not grow without bound

Context: IAMs also contain additional external critiques unrelated to CES misuse, including sensitivity to discount rates, questionable climate damage functions that understate catastrophic tail risks, and reliance on exogenous GDP growth assumptions
